questions.text: A 25-year-old student presents with a 10-day history of dry cough, mild fever, and fatigue, but has been able to attend daily activities. Chest X-ray shows patchy infiltrates and a physical exam reveals mild crackles. Which of the following is the LEAST likely causative agent of this patient's condition?
A 55-year-old male with a history of heavy smoking presents with a cough and sputum production for 4 months. Which statement is true regarding his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Diagnosis requires symptoms for at least 2 consecutive months.

options.label: B
options.text: Smoking cessation is the only intervention that positively impacts COPD

options.label: C
options.text: Inhaled bronchodilators are the primary treatment for chronic bronchitis. .

options.label: D
options.text: Hemoptysis is the initial symptom indicative of chronic bronchitis

questions.correct_answer: B. Smoking cessation is the only intervention that positively impacts COPD
questions.explanation:
Chronic Bronchitis

Cough and sputum production lasting for at least 3 months in each of 2 consecutive years. (Option A ruled out)

One of the phenotypes associated with COPD, alongside emphysema.large bronchi overtime become inflamed and scarred.

Cigarette smoking (95% of COPD cases in the UK attributed to tobacco smoke).

Initial symptoms include cough, sputum production, and "smoker's cough"; hemoptysis may occur during exacerbations. (Option D ruled out)

Consider chronic asthma, tuberculosis, bronchiectasis, congestive heart failure.

Chest X-ray, blood count, and alpha-1 antitrypsin assay to rule out other conditions.

Reduce exposure to harmful particles and manage symptoms.

Smoking cessation (only intervention that positively impacts COPD) (Option B), inhaled bronchodilators (Option C ruled out), glucocorticoids.

Generally progressive; influenced by age (inversely related) and post-bronchodilator FEV1 (directly related).

Weight loss, pulmonary hypertension; common causes of death include respiratory failure, cardiac disease, and lung cancer.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with progressive dyspnea and a history of smoking for 25 years. Imaging studies reveal abnormal enlargement of air spaces distal to the terminal bronchioles. Which of the following types of emphysema is most likely seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Centriacinar

Enlarged air spaces primarily in the central part of the acinus. (Option C) seen in chronic smokers, upper lobe of lungs are predominantly affected.

Panacinar

Uniform enlargement of air spaces throughout the acinus. (Option A ruled out) seen with congenital alpha 1 antitrypsin deficiency in younger age group.lower lobes of lung are commonly involved.associated with liver failure.

Paraseptal

Enlargement occurs near the pleura or septa. (Option B ruled out) increase risk of spontaneous pneumothorax.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male, with a 30-year history of smoking, presents with a chronic productive cough for the last 2 years, worsening shortness of breath, and recent weight loss. Examination reveals bilateral wheezing and peripheral edema.imaging shows alveolar wall destruction beyond terminal bronchiole. Which of the following pathophysiological mechanisms is primarily responsible for his condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Airflow limitation due to loss of elastic tissue

options.label: D
options.text: Hypersecretion of mucus from goblet cells

questions.correct_answer: C. Airflow limitation due to loss of elastic tissue
questions.explanation:
Pulmonary Components

Description

Mucus hypersecretion

Enlargement of mucus glands and goblet cells → chronic bronchitis (cough + sputum for ≥3 months/year). (Option D ruled out)

Emphysema

Alveolar destruction by proteases and oxidants → permanent enlargement of distal airspaces.

Airflow Limitation

Loss of elastic tissue + inflammation → premature airway closure, gas trapping, and hyperinflation.

This is the primary mechanism for the airflow limitation. (Option C)

Pulmonary vascular remodeling

Structural changes in pulmonary vessels.eventually causing PAH. (Option A ruled out)

Systemic Components

Description

Weight Loss

Altered fat metabolism.

Skeletal Muscle Dysfunction

Muscle impairment reduces physical capacity.

Peripheral Edema

Impaired kidney function → salt and water retention.

Osteoporosis

Decreased bone density.

Increased Inflammatory Markers

Elevated systemic inflammation contributes to complications.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with worsening asthma symptoms, fever, and a rash consisting of purpura on her lower extremities. Laboratory findings reveal eosinophilia (1200 cells/μL) and elevated inflammatory markers. A biopsy of the skin lesion shows extravascular granulomas. Which of the following statements about her condition is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Patients often present with systemic symptoms like malaise and weight loss.

options.label: B
options.text: The condition typically involves necrotizing vasculitis affecting small and medium-sized blood vessels.

options.label: C
options.text: Cardiac involvement may lead to complications such as myocarditis and pericarditis.

options.label: D
options.text: It primarily affects large blood vessels, leading to significant vascular occlusion.

questions.correct_answer: D. It primarily affects large blood vessels, leading to significant vascular occlusion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with chronic shortness of breath, dry cough, fatigue, and weight loss for the past six months. He works in a pigeon breeding facility and reports worsening symptoms over time. High-resolution CT (HRCT) of the chest reveals reticular changes, ground-glass opacities, and traction bronchiectasis. Which of the following statements about his condition is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is caused by a Type I hypersensitivity reaction mediated by IgE antibodies.

options.label: B
options.text: Pulmonary fibrosis is a known complication of chronic HP.

options.label: C
options.text: Acute HP presents with symptoms several days after antigen exposure.

options.label: D
options.text: HRCT is typically normal in hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

questions.correct_answer: B. Pulmonary fibrosis is a known complication of chronic HP.
questions.explanation:
Disease

Antigen

Source

Farmer’s lung

Thermophilic actinomycetes (e.g., Saccharopolyspora rectivirgula); fungus

Grain, mouldy hay, silage

Bagassosis

Thermophilic actinomycetes

Sugarcane

Bird fancier’s lung

Proteins derived from parakeets, pigeons, budgerigars

Bird feathers, droppings, serum proteins

Hot tub lung

Cladosporium species; Mycobacterium avium complex

Contaminated water, mould on ceiling

Woodworker’s lung

Alternaria species; Bacillus subtilis

Oak, cedar, pine, mahogany dusts

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with a history of asthma presents with symptoms occurring more than three times a week and nocturnal awakenings at least once a week. After evaluating the patient's condition, the physician decides to initiate treatment. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase the dose of short-acting β2-agonist.

options.label: C
options.text: Start prednisolone at the lowest effective dose.

questions.explanation:
Step

Description

Key Points

Step 1

Occasional Short-Acting β2-Agonists(rescue therapy)
  • For mild, intermittent asthma (symptoms <1/week, <2 nocturnal episodes/month).
  • Use bronchodilators like salbutamol or terbutaline as needed.

Step 2

Regular Preventer Therapy
  • Initiate if exacerbations occur within 2 years or symptoms are frequent (≥3/week) or nocturnal awakenings occur weekly.
  • Inhaled Glucocorticoids (ICS): e.g., beclometasone, budesonide (starting dose: 400 μg/day for adults).
  • Alternatives: Chromones, leukotriene receptor antagonists, theophyllines.

Step 3

Add-on Therapy
  • Review adherence, inhaler technique, and aggravating factors if poorly controlled.
  • Increase ICS dose or add Long-Acting β2-Agonist (LABA); combination inhalers are beneficial. (Options A & D ruled out)
  • Consider oral leukotriene receptor antagonists (e.g., montelukast 10 mg/day) if needed.

Step 4

Addition of a Fourth Drug
  • For inadequate control with moderate ICS dose, increase to 2000 μg/day or add nasal glucocorticoids for upper airway symptoms.
  • Other options: Long-acting antimuscarinics, theophyllines, slow-release β2-agonists.
  • Discontinue ineffective add-on therapies.

Step 5

Continuous/Frequent Oral Glucocorticoids
  • Prescribe prednisolone at the lowest effective dose, typically in the morning. (Option C ruled out)
  • Monitor for systemic side effects (long-term use risks).
  • Consider Omalizumab for atopic patients or Mepolizumab for eosinophilic cases.
  • Immunosuppressants are less common due to variable efficacy and side effects.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with wheezing and shortness of breath, worsening at night. His symptoms are triggered by dust and pet dander. Spirometry shows an obstructive pattern that improves with a bronchodilator. What is the underlying mechanism?

A 35-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with a non-productive cough, dyspnea, and low-grade fever. A Gomori methenamine silver stain of a bronchoalveolar lavage specimen was done. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A 70 y/o man with COPD presents with 3 days of worsening shortness of breath, fever, and productive cough. He appears confused and has a respiratory rate of 32/min, BP of 85/55 mmHg, and BUN of 25 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: B
options.text: Inpatient treatment with levofloxacin and azithromycin

options.label: C
options.text: ICU admission with piperacillin-tazobactam and vancomycin

questions.correct_answer: C. ICU admission with piperacillin-tazobactam and vancomycin
questions.explanation:
CURB-65

Symptom

Score

(C) Confusion

1

(U) Urea: BUN >19mg/dL (>7 mmol/L)

1

(R) Respiratory rate ≥30/min

1

(B) Blood Pressure – Systolic BP ≤90 mmHg or diastolic BP ≤60 mmHg

1

(65) Age ≥65 years

1

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding breath sounds?

options.label: A
options.text: Vesicular breath sounds are soft, low-pitched sounds heard at the bronchus

options.label: B
options.text: Bronchial sounds are loud, high-pitched best heard at lung bases of normal lung

options.label: C
options.text: Egophony is the increased resonance of voice sounds heard when auscultating the lungs

options.label: D
options.text: Whispered pectoriloquy rules out the presence of lung consolidation

questions.correct_answer: C. Egophony is the increased resonance of voice sounds heard when auscultating the lungs
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Egophony - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  • ↳ Lung Sounds - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  • ↳ Whispered pectoriloquy – Knowledge and References

Feature

Bronchial Sounds

(Option B ruled out)

Vesicular Sounds

(Option A ruled out)

Origin

Tracheobronchial tree

Finer lung parenchyma

Characteristics

Loud, harsh, high-pitched

Soft, low-pitched

Timing

Predominantly expiratory

Predominantly inspiratory

Location

Heard over the trachea or right apex

Best appreciated at posterior lung bases

Abnormality

Abnormal if heard in other areas

Normal in healthy lung areas

questions.text: Which of the following statements are false regarding primary lung abscesses?

options.label: B
options.text: Hematologic dissemination is one of the causes

options.label: C
options.text: poor dental hygiene is an independent risk factor for developing lung abscesses

options.label: D
options.text: Staphylococcus aureus can cause lung abscesses in individuals with alcohol use disorder

questions.correct_answer: B. Hematologic dissemination is one of the causes

questions.text: A 72 y/o male, a k/c/o COPD presents to the ED with shortness of breath and confusion. He has been experiencing increased fatigue and worsening dyspnea over the past few days. O/E he has a respiratory rate of 30 bpm. Arterial blood gas analysis shows: PaO2: 58 mmHg, PaCO2: 52 mmHg and pH: 7.2. Which type of respiratory failure is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Type 1 Respiratory Failure

(Option A ruled out)

Type 2 Respiratory Failure

Definition

Hypoxemic respiratory failure

Hypercapnic respiratory failure

PaO2

PaO2 < 60 mmHg

May be normal or decreased

PaCO2

Normal or decreased

PaCO2 > 45 mmHg

pH

Typically normal

< 7.35 due to acidosis

A-a Gradient

Can be normal (low FiO₂/Patm, hypoventilation) or increased (V/Q mismatch, shunt, diffusion defect)

Variable, depending on hypoventilation or dead space

Primary Causes

  
  • V/Q mismatch
  • Diffusion defect
  • Right-to-left shunt
  • Low FiO₂/Patm
  • Hypoventilation
  • Respiratory pump failure
  • Decreased central drive
  • Neuromuscular impairment
  • Increased CO₂ production

Common Etiologies
  • ARDS
  • COPD
  • Congestive heart failure
  • High altitude
  • Pneumonia
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • AV malformation
  • CNS depression (e.g., sedatives)
  • Neuromuscular diseases (e.g., ALS)
  • Chest wall/pleural disorders (e.g., flail chest, kyphoscoliosis)

questions.text: Which of the following represents the correct order of pathological stages in classic pneumonia?

options.label: A
options.text: Edema Stage → Gray Hepatization → Red Hepatization → Resolution Stage

options.label: B
options.text: Edema Stage → Red Hepatization → Gray Hepatization → Resolution Stage

options.label: C
options.text: Gray Hepatization → Red Hepatization → Edema Stage → Resolution Stage

options.label: D
options.text: Red Hepatization → Resolution Stage → Edema Stage → Gray Hepatization

questions.correct_answer: B. Edema Stage → Red Hepatization → Gray Hepatization → Resolution Stage

questions.text: A 45 y/o man with a history of bronchiectasis presents for follow-up after sputum analysis reveals Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection. What is the recommended treatment regimen for this patient's infection?
questions.explanation:
Antibiotic Treatment:


 
  • Acute Exacerbations: Target common pathogens (Haemophilus influenzae, Pseudomonas aeruginosa) for at least 7–10 days.
  • NTM Infections: Complex treatment with specific diagnostic criteria, requiring multiple positive sputum cultures and histopathological evidence.
  • Regimen for MAC: For macrolide-sensitive MAC in HIV-negative patients: macrolide + rifampin + ethambutol.

Bronchial Hygiene:
  • Enhance secretion clearance with hydration, mucolytics, bronchodilators, hyperosmolar agents, and chest physiotherapy.
  • Pulmonary rehabilitation and exercise
  • Use mucolytic dornase (DNase) in CF-related bronchiectasis; avoid it in non-CF cases.

Anti-Inflammatory Therapy:
  • Inhaled glucocorticoids may reduce dyspnea and sputum production; with limited effect on lung function or exacerbation rates.
  • Consider oral/systemic glucocorticoids for bronchiectasis due to ABPA and autoimmune diseases.
  • Itraconazole may benefit ABPA patients. (Option A ruled out)

Refractory Cases:
  • Surgical resection for localized suppuration; lung transplantation for advanced bronchiectasis.

Complications:
  • Recurrent infections can cause antibiotic resistance and severe hemoptysis, requiring intubation, identification of bleeding sources, and possible bronchial artery embolization or surgery.

Prevention:
  • Address immunodeficiencies with gamma globulin, vaccinate against influenza and pneumococcus, and consider suppressive antibiotics (daily oral, rotating schedules, macrolides, inhaled, or intermittent IV) for patients with recurrent infections.

questions.text: A 35 y/o male presents with a chronic productive cough, dyspnea, and occasional hemoptysis. A chest radiograph of the patient is given. Which investigation would be most appropriate for confirming the provisional diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Bronchiectasis - Tram track sign

X-ray

HRCT

 

Black arrows pointing to tram track sign

 

Red arrows pointing to tram track sign

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly associated with bronchiectasis affecting the lower lobes?
questions.explanation:
Lobe Involvement in Bronchiectasis

Upper Lung Fields

Mid Lung Fields

Lower Lung Fields

Central Airways
  • Cystic Fibrosis (Option A ruled out)
  • Post-radiation Fibrosis
  • Nontuberculous Mycobacterial (NTM) Infection (Option C ruled out)
  • Dyskinetic/ Immotile Cilia Syndrome.
  • AAT-1 deficiency
  • Brocks syndrome
  • Yellow nail syndrome
  • Chronic Recurrent Aspiration: Conditions like esophageal motility disorders result in aspiration. (Option D)
  • End-stage Fibrotic Lung Disease: Traction bronchiectasis as a result of parenchymal distortion and fibrosis.
  • Hypogammaglobulinemia
  • Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA) (Option B ruled out)
  • Congenital conditions that primarily impact the central airways: Tracheobronchomegaly (Mounier-Kuhn Syndrome) and Williams-Campbell Syndrome

questions.text: A 60 y/o woman presents with the characteristic fingers as shown in the image, along with chronic cough, daily production of large amounts of purulent sputum and a history of recurrent lung infections over the past several years. Her CT scan revealed the following findings. A biopsy of the affected lung tissue is performed. Which of the following histopathological findings is most likely present?

options.label: D
options.text: Bronchiectatic cavities lined exclusively by ciliated epithelium

questions.explanation:
Bronchiectasis

Irreversible dilation of the bronchi leads to chronic airway infection and progressive lung damage.

Types

Areas Involved

Pathological Features
  • Cylindrical (Tubular): Most common.
  • Varicose.
  • Cystic.
  • Focal Bronchiectasis: Localized and is due to airway obstruction (e.g., tumour, foreign body).
  • Diffuse Bronchiectasis: Widespread, from systemic or infectious causes.
  • Bronchiectatic cavities lined by granulation tissue, squamous epithelium, or normal ciliated epithelium. (Option D)
  • Inflammatory changes in bronchial walls.
  • Bronchial artery hypertrophy.
  • Chronic inflammation and fibrosis lead to the destruction of normal lung tissue in advanced cases.

questions.text: A 50 y/o male presents with worsening dyspnea. His pulmonary function test reveals a significant reduction in DLCO. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the low DLCO?
questions.explanation:
Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide (DLCO)

The DLCO test measures how much CO moves from the alveoli into the red blood cells each minute. This test is vital because it shows how efficiently the lungs can transfer oxygen from the air we breathe into the bloodstream, making it an important tool for diagnosing and tracking various lung conditions.

Increased DLCO

Decreased DLCO

Increases with increased availability of surface area and haemoglobin in capillaries

Due to the thickened or destruction of the alveolar membrane and factors affecting vasculature.
  • Asthma
  • Polycythemia
  • Acute congestive heart failure (Option D ruled out)
  • Exercise
  • Obesity (Option B ruled out)
  • Pulmonary haemorrhage (Option A ruled out)
  • Altitude
  • Bronchodilator usage
  • Pulmonary fibrosis (Option C)
  • Emphysema
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Anaemia
  • COPD
  • Bronchiolitis
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Pleural effusion

questions.text: A 45 y/o man with a history of COPD presents with shortness of breath, cough, and increased sputum production. His arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows hypoxemia, and his calculated A-a gradient is elevated. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the elevated A-a gradient in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type 1 Respiratory Failure Etiologies

Normal A-a gradient

Increased A-a gradient
  • Alveolar hypoventilation
  • Low atmospheric pressure/ Fracture of inspired oxygen
  • Diffusion defect: Impaired gas exchange leading to ↓PaO₂ due to thickened alveolar membrane. In emphysema and Interstitial Lung disease.
  • V/Q mismatch: Most common cause of Hypoxemia. Occurs when there is an imbalance between ventilation and perfusion. Examples - COPD, Asthma pulmonary embolism, ARDS, CHF
  • Right to left shunts - Blood bypasses the lungs without gas exchange.

questions.text: A 72-year-old female patient presents with progressive shortness of breath and a persistent dry cough. She has a history of pulmonary fibrosis diagnosed two years ago. Spirometry shows reduced lung volumes. Which of the following is most likely true regarding this patient’s spirometry results?

options.label: A
options.text: FVC is likely to be increased.

options.label: C
options.text: TLC is likely normal or increased.

options.label: D
options.text: RV is likely normal or increased.

questions.explanation:
Parameter

Description

Normal Value

(Litres)

Tidal Volume (TV)

The volume of air inhaled or exhaled in one cycle

0.5 - 0.7 L

Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV)

Additional air that can be forcibly inhaled after normal inhalation

1.5 - 3.0 L

Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV)

Additional air that can be forcibly exhaled after normal exhalation

1.0 - 1.5 L

Residual Volume (RV)

The volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximum exhalation

1.0 - 1.5 L

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)

Maximum volume the lungs can hold (TV + IRV + ERV + RV)

4.5 - 6.0 L

Vital Capacity (VC)

Total air that can be exhaled after maximum inhalation (TV + IRV + ERV)

3.0 - 5.0 L

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC)

The volume of air remaining after normal exhalation (ERV + RV)

2.0 - 2.5 L

Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1)

The volume of air forcefully exhaled in the first second of a forced expiration

3.0 - 4.0 L

Forced Vital Capacity (FVC)

Total amount of air exhaled during a forced expiration

3.5 - 5.0 L

Predicted Postoperative FEV1 (PPO FEV1)

Postoperative risk assessment parameter for thoracic surgery

Varies based on patient's condition

questions.text: Match the following diseases with their respective flow volume curves: Asthma a) 2. Extrathoracic Obstruction b) 3.Thoracic obstruction c) 4.Restrictive airway disorder d)
questions.explanation:
Conditions

Flow Volume Loops

Normal (article)

A normal flow-volume loop displays airflow (in L/second) related to lung volume (in L) during maximal inspiration from residual volume (RV) and maximum expiration from total lung capacity (TLC).

Asthma (Airflow Obstruction):

  • Narrowed airways due to smooth muscle constriction and inflammation reduce expiratory airflow, causing a “scooped” appearance, especially at lower lung volumes.
  • Flow may improve after bronchodilator use.

Retrosternal Goiter (Extrathoracic Obstruction):

  • Extrathoracic airway narrowing can limit inspiratory flow, causing flattening of the inspiratory portion of the loop.

Intrathoracic Fixed Obstruction:

  • Fixed airway obstruction within the chest affects both inspiration and expiration, resulting in flattened, plateaued loops on both sides of the flow-volume curve.
  

Restrictive Airway Disorders (e.g., Pulmonary Fibrosis):

  • High lung recoil pressure increases expiratory flow for any given lung volume, producing a loop that is shifted to lower volumes and shows high maximal flow relative to volume.
  • Overall lung volumes (TLC, FRC) are reduced due to increased stiffness.

questions.text: A 55 y/o male with h/o pneumonia is admitted to the hospital with severe shortness of breath. O/E, his oxygen saturation is 85%, and arterial blood gas analysis shows: PaO2: 55 mmHg PaCO2: 40 mmHg pH: 7.38 He is anxious and struggling to breathe. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient’s respiratory failure?

options.label: C
options.text: Oxygen therapy via a nonrebreathing mask

questions.correct_answer: C. Oxygen therapy via a nonrebreathing mask
questions.explanation:
Respiratory Failure

Treatment

Type 1 Respiratory Failure (Hypoxemic)
  • Correct Hypoxemia: Aim to achieve PaO₂ ≥ 60 mmHg or SaO₂ 90-94%.
  • Oxygen Therapy: Use nasal cannula, face mask, nonrebreathing mask, or high-flow nasal cannula.
  • Avoid Oxygen Toxicity: Monitor to avoid excessive oxygen, which may lead to oxygen toxicity and CO₂ narcosis.
  • Refractory Cases: Consider extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) if hypoxemia persists despite conventional oxygen therapy.

Type 2 Respiratory Failure (Hypercapnic)
  • Correct Hypercapnia and Acidosis: Address the underlying cause and consider ventilatory support if needed.
  • Noninvasive Ventilation (NIV): Preferred for conditions like COPD exacerbation, cardiogenic pulmonary edema, and obesity hypoventilation syndrome. (Option B ruled out)
  • Ventilatory Support: Intubate and provide mechanical ventilation if severe, with goals to:
    • Correct hypoxemia and respiratory acidosis
    • Relieve ventilatory muscle fatigue
  • Mechanical Ventilation Indications: Apnea, respiratory rate >30, impaired consciousness, hemodynamic instability, or arterial pH < 7.25.

Type 3 Respiratory Failure
  • Pain management
  • Chest physiotherapy
  • Incentive spirometry
  • Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)
  • Intubation

Type 4 Respiratory Failure
  • Intubation for respiratory support
  • Reduce oxygen consumption during resuscitation

questions.text: A 65 y/o female undergoes elective hip replacement surgery. Postoperatively, she develops shortness of breath and a decreased oxygen saturation level. She reports significant pain at the surgical site and is reluctant to take deep breaths due to discomfort. O/E, her respiratory rate is elevated, and auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds at the bases. A chest X-ray shows areas of atelectasis. What type of respiratory failure is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Type 3 Respiratory Failure

(Postoperative)

Type 4 Respiratory Failure

(Shock-Related) (Option D ruled out)

Definition

Respiratory failure due to atelectasis from postoperative factors

Respiratory failure due to high metabolic demands from shock

Primary Cause

Atelectasis

Increased metabolic demands exceed respiratory capacity.

Mechanism

Alveolar collapse prevents oxygen from entering the bloodstream

The respiratory system cannot meet oxygen demands (e.g., sepsis, fever).

Common Etiologies
  • Pain post-surgery
  • Sedative use
  • Anesthesia effects
  • Sepsis
  • Fever
  • Cardiac events (e.g., heart attack)
  • Blood loss leading to shock

Management Strategy

Often involves supportive measures, pain management, Chest physiotherapy, Incentive spirometry, Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), Intubation and monitoring

Intubation for respiratory support and to reduce oxygen consumption during resuscitation.

Respiratory Failure type

Definition

PaO2

PaCO2

Etiologies

Type 1 (Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure)

Low oxygen levels without elevated CO2

PaO2 < 50 mmHg

PaCO2 < 60 mmHg

- Alveolar hypoventilation (e.g., obesity hypoventilation)

- Low FiO2 (high altitudes)

- Diffusion defects (e.g., emphysema)

- V/Q mismatch (e.g., ARDS, COPD, pulmonary embolism)

- Right-to-left shunt (e.g., pneumonia)

Type 2 (Hypercapnic Respiratory Failure)

Inadequate ventilation with elevated CO2

PaO2 < 50 mmHg

PaCO2 > 60 mmHg

- CNS dysfunction (e.g., stroke, encephalopathy, ALS)

- Sedatives (e.g., opiates, alcohol)

- Chest wall abnormalities (e.g., kyphoscoliosis, obesity)

- Respiratory muscle dysfunction

- Ventilation issues (e.g., diaphragm dysfunction)

Type 3 (Peri-Operative Respiratory Failure)

Post-surgical respiratory failure related to impaired breathing

PaO2 < 50 mmHg

PaCO2 < 60 mmHg

- General anesthesia

- Supine position

- Depressed cough reflex

- Abdominal incisions

- Ascites

- Airway secretions

Type 4 (Shock with Hypoperfusion)

Respiratory failure due to shock-induced metabolic demand

PaO2 < 50 mmHg

PaCO2 > 60 mmHg

- High metabolic demand (e.g., septic shock, fever, exercise)

- Reduced cardiac output (e.g., cardiogenic, hypovolemic shock)
